Award.AwardTitle: Whistler Mode Radio Sounding of Electrons, Ions and Density Irregularities in the Inner Magnetosphere from 90 to 5000 km
Award.AbstractNarration:
Determining the density and composition of plasma in the inner magnetosphere is a largely unexplored area of magnetospheric and ionospheric research. Using recently developed whistler mode (WM) radio sounding techniques and data from a new generation of space- and ground-based experiments, this three-year research program will investigate inner magnetospheric plasma density, ion composition and density irregularities from 90 to 5000km. Four research projects have been proposed:
(1) Use WM radio sounding data from the Radio Plasma Imager (RPI) on the IMAGE satellite to measure the cold-plasma density (Ne), ion composition (H+, O+, He+) and density irregularities (10m to 10km scale size) along a magnetic field line as a function of geophysical conditions (e.g. location, local time, plasmapause position, geomagnetic and solar activity).
(2) Study the variation (loss and refilling) of electron density and ion composition along geomagnetic field lines before, during, and after geomagnetic storms.
(3) Build empirical models of plasma density, ion composition and density irregularities as functions of geophysical conditions along B0 from 90-5,000km.
(4) Combine WM sounding results with those from complementary ground based (e.g. ionosonde, magnetometer), spacecraft based in situ (e.g. DMSP, CHAMP, CRESS, POLAR) and radio sounding (e.g. RPI sounding at higher altitude in free space modes) to augment and extend the empirical models and to build new field aligned models of the inner magnetospheric plasma density and composition up to equatorial altitudes.
These empirical models will be used to gain new understanding into processes and mechanisms important to magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling and for use in space weather predictions. As a result these results should have broad application in space physics research. The proposal will support a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When the Radio Plasma Imager (RPI) on the IMAGE (Imager for Magnetopause-to-Aurora Global Exploration) satellite operates in the inner magnetosphere at ~90-5000 km altitudes, pulses emitted at ~3-300-KHz sounding frequency range can propagate in the whistler Mode (WM). WM radio sounding was not feasible from previous satellites, as they used radio sounder frequency ranges above the WM frequency range. Unlike other modes of propagation operating at higher frequencies, WM propagation is influenced by both electron density and ion composition and propagates close to the geomagnetic field.  With these unique propagation features, WM sounding from IMAGE has provided, for the first time, radio sounding of both electrons and ion densities along the geomagnetic field line passing through the satellite. The principle outcomes of this research are the following: (1) First measurements of field-aligned electron and ion (H+, He+, and O+) densities as a function of major- and moderate-geomagnetic storm activity. These measurements have led to several new features of plasma behavior during geomagnetic storms, including oscillations in plasmaspheric electron and H+ densities and increase in the O+/H+ transition height by ~500 km. (2) Interpretation of variations in plasma density and composition in terms of the variations in thermospheric parameters, such as neutral particle density and composition, neutral wind, and electric field.  The interpretation was based on comparing observations with physics-based simulations using SAMI2 model (Naval Research Laboratory (NRL) ionosphere model) of the ionospheric dynamics. The intellectual merit of this research lies in providing the first measurements of field-aligned electron and ion densities as a function of geomagnetic storm activity and demonstrating the use of physics-based models in interpreting such measurements.  This observation/simulation approach, on one hand, provides new understanding of ionosphere-thermosphere-coupling, and, on the other hand, provides new ways to test existing theories of the physics of this coupling. The broader impact of this research is that it potentially contributes to the emerging field of space weather monitoring, improvements in accuracy of GPS devices and in calculations of drag on ionospheric satellites. The research has led to the training of a doctoral student and a postdoctoral fellow.
